dc:title: The regulation of leaf, ramet and genet densities in experimental populations of the rhizomatous perennial Solidago canadensis.
dc:creator: Hartnett D.C.
dc:description: Populations of Solidago canadensis were grown from seed at 3 different stem densities for 28 months. During the 1st growing season increasing density resulted in reductions in leaf-population growth rates, ramet biomass, number of flower heads, and reproductive 'allocation', and a delay in flowering. In contrast, there was negligible mortality in response to high density during the first growing season. Clonal growth was also density-dependent; both the length of new rhizomes and the number produced per ramet were reduced with increasing density. As new rhizomes were produced in autumn some emerged to form leafy rosettes and others remained underground. Rosettes had higher survivorship and made a greater contribution to the next season's ramet population than did the mature underground rhizomes. Overall shoot densities were regulated by a combination of ramet and genet deaths and density-dependent ramet birth within clones. At high densities, genet motality and clonal expansion of the survivors resulted in a decreasing number but increasing size of genets over time. The relationship between ramet weight and density of interconnected ramets did not conform to the 'law of constant final yield' predicted for populations of individual plants. This also indicates that ecologically, Solidago ramets are not functionally independent 'individuals'. -from Authors

dc:title: Seed dynamics and factors limiting recruitment of the mallee Eucalyptus incrassata, in semi-arid, south-eastern Australia.
dc:creator: Wellington A.B.
dc:description: Seedling recruitment in long-unburnt stands of yellow mallee was limited by a low availability of viable seed in the soil and by the inability of new seedlings to survive. The hypothesis that fire-induced mass release of seed may facilitate recruitment through the establishment of a seed bank in the soil was supported. Successful establishment after fire, and the general absence of seedlings from unburnt stands, strongly suggest that the effects of fire in modifying environmental factors are crucial for seedling recruitment of mallees. -from Authors

dc:title: Role of allelopathy, heat and charred wood in the germination of chaparral herbs and suffrutescents.
dc:creator: Keeley J.
dc:description: Herbaceous perennials are often dormant under the chaparral canopy and their presence in burnt areas is due to sprouts from bulbs or rhizomes. Their seeds germinated readily without any treatment and they were not inhibited by leachate from living Adenostoma fasciculatum foliage, but high temperatures were lethal to seeds of many species. Suffrutescents are not present under the chaparral canopy and their presence in burnt areas is due entirely to seed; germination was stimulated by heat, or powdered charred wood, or both. Opportunisic annuals have polymorphic seeds: a portion germinated readily whereas others germinated only after heat or charred wood treatment. The non-refractory seeds account for colonization into gaps in the canopy and the refractory portion accounts for their abundance immediately after a fire. Whether or not the non-refractory seeds are inhibited by allelopathic leachate frm the A. fasciculatum canopy is equivocal. Fire-annual species are largely restricted to recently burnt chaparral sites and the seeds of these species remain dormant in the soil between fires. There is little germination without cues relating to fire. Some species responded to heat but the highest germination was with the charred wood or heat plus charred wood treatments. -from Authors

dc:title: Clonal growth in Typha latifolia: population dynamics and demography of the ramets.
dc:creator: Dickerman J.
dc:description: In a mature natural population of Typha latifolia in south-central Michigan, shoots emerged in 3 main pulses each year, resulting in 3 major cohorts. The 1st cohort emerged in early spring, grew throughout the summer and senesced completely in late autumn. The 2nd emerged in midsummer; 82% (yr 1) and 76% (yr 2) of these shoots senesced completely in autumn, while the remainder resumed growth the following spring. The 3rd emerged in late summer and early autumn; 78% (yr 1) and 92% (yr 2) of all its shoots resumed growth the following spring. Shoot mortality within 3 wk of emergence was minor. The ranges of live shoot density were very similar for the 2 years: 12.7-43.9 shoots m-2 in yr 1 versus 11.2-41.9 shoots m-2 in yr 2. In yr 1, however, live shoot density increased gradually throughout the growing season, while in yr 2 a rapid increase in shoot density resulted in a density of 40.1 shoots m-2 by mid-May. This density was maintained throughout the 2nd growing season. Because the density of shoots growing from early spring was 60% greater in yr 2, the applicability of genet-based, density-mediated competition theory (based on eight expected consequences) to ramet-level populations could be evaluated. Density-mediated competition does not appear to regulate ramet populations in mature stands of T. latifolia. -from Authors

dc:title: Jamaican montane forests: nutrient capital and cost of growth.
dc:creator: Tanner E.
dc:description: Arithmetic mean concentrations in leaf and composite stem samples in Mor Ridge forest were, respectively (in mg g-1), N, 11.1, 2.0; P, 0.64, 0.15; K, 4.3, 1.6; Ca, 8.0, 1.9; Mg, 3.3, 0.80. The corresponding concentrations for well-developed Mull Ridge forest were N, 17.8, 3.1; P, 0.76, 0.13; K, 11.7, 3.1; Ca, 10.0, 3.0; Mg, 4.6, 0.61. Concentrations per unit area (kg ha-1) and (in parentheses) per unit dry weight (mg g-1) of above-ground standing crop were lower in the lower stature, slower growing Mor ridge forest: N, 426 (2.0); P, 29.7 (0.14); K, 272 (1.3); Ca, 353 (1.7); Mg, 155 (0.74) than in the well-developed Mull Ridge forest: N, 857 (2.5); P, 41.2 (0.12); K, 829 (2.5); Ca, 940 (2.8); Mg, 193 (0.57). Impoverishment of the Mor Ridge forest compared to the well-developed Mull Ridge forest is probably due to the limitation of growth by the supply of N and K, and possibly by P and Ca. Impoverishment of the Jamaican Upper Montane Rain forest compared to better-developed Montane Rain forests at higher altitudes on larger mountains is probably not a result of poor supply of N, K, Ca or Mg, though the role of P is still not clear. -from Author

dc:title: The possible role of phosphate in the salinity tolerance of Lavatera arborea.
dc:creator: Okusanya O.
dc:description: Additional phosphate enhanced growth in non-saline and saline conditions, but growth was most in 40% sea water with additional phosphate. The limit of salt tolerance of this species without additional phosphate was c50% sea water but the limit was increased with additional phosphate. Phosphate enhanced root growth at high salinity and resulted in increased K, Ca, Mg and P contents in the shoot. -from Authors

dc:title: Growth, survival and reproduction of two species of marine algae at different densities in natural stands.
dc:creator: Schiel D.
dc:description: Monospecific stands of an annual, Sargassum sinclairii, and a perennial, Carpophyllum maschalocarpum, were monitored from recruitment in northern New Zealand. Individuals of both species grew faster and attained a larger size in the high-density stands. Survivorship rates fluctuated throughout the year for low- and high-density S. sinclairii, but a higher proportion of low-density plants survived at the end of the year. Carpophyllum plants showed higher survivorship at low density, but all plants in these stands which remained at the end of the study were stunted. Size-frequency distributions through time tended to be positively skewed for both low- and high-density stands of S. sinclairii. Some 92% of S. sinclairii plants became reproductive in high-density stands, compared with 46% at low density; 40% of C. maschalocarpum plants became fertile after the 2nd year of growth at high-density, while none of the low-density plants became reproductive. The bearing of receptacles is clearly related to plant size, and most plants of both species at low density did not attain a large enough size to reproduce. The greatest recruitment for S. sinclarii occurred near dense adult stands. -from Author

dc:title: Vegetation development following fire in Picea mariana ( black spruce) - Pleurozium forests of south-eastern Labrador, Canada.
dc:creator: Foster D.
dc:description: Macrofossil analysis of mor humus profiles in mature stands yields the following stratigraphy: mineral soil-charcoal-Polytrichum juniperinum-Cladonia lichens-Pleurozium schreberi-feather mosses and Sphagnum girgensohnii. The pattern of vegetation development, especially of the arboreal species, is significantly different from that reported for the central and western boreal forest in North America, attributed to the much longer fire cycle in the maritime region of Labrador which allows the accumulation of a thick organic soil layer that is incompletely removed by fire. Arboreal regeneration is slow due to the limited availability of mineral soil seed-beds. The progressive establishment of black spruce and balsam fir Abies balsamea over a 70-100 yr period results in an uneven age structure and provides a long period when lichen woodlands cover the landscape. Most of the vascular understorey species follow the pattern of initial floristics and resprout rapidly following fire. Coptis groenlandicum, Gaultheria hispidula and Empetrum nigrum decrease following fire whereas only Epilobium angustifolium shows a marked increase. The cryptogam ground cover undergoes a physiognomic and compositional succession that represents contrasting substrate requirements and the differential response of the major species to a temporally-varying environment. -from Author

dc:title: Variation in seed production and germination of Spartina anglica within a zoned saltmarsh.
dc:creator: Marks T.
dc:description: The saltmarsh at Southport, Merseyside, supported 4 zones of Spartina anglica sward which, from seaward to landward, were named pioneer, transitional, mature, and invaded zones. Mean density of inflorescences varied from nearly 4 m-2 in the pioneer zone to >112 m-2 in the adjacent transitional zone. The upper reaches of the marsh had intermediate densities. Inflorescences from the upper zones were large and bore at least twice as many spikelets as those from lower zones, but the proportion of mature, filled seeds per inflorescence was inversely related to the number of spikelets borne on it resulting in a marked difference between zones in the production of viable seed. The zone of most vigorous vegetative growth and largest inflorescences thus produced the smallest proportion of viable seed. Germination of seeds was accelerated by cool (5oC), moist and brief (60 day) storage. Length of photoperiod had no significant effect on germination. Salt water was inhibitory. There were significant interactions between factors. Overall production of viable seeds was low (<6%) and 77% of potentially viable seed was produced in 16% of the total marsh area examined. -Authors

dc:title: Litho-, humic- and pollen stratigraphy at Quick Moss, Northumberland.
dc:creator: Rowell T.
dc:description: Radiocarbon dates indicate that the peat has been forming for the last 8000 yr. Pollen concentration is shown to be a function not of pollen influx, but of the relative accumulation rate of the peat.-from Authors

dc:title: Pollen limitation in a monocarpic species, Ipomopsis aggregata.
dc:creator: Hainsworth F.
dc:description: Tested whether seed production in the perennial monocarpic plant Ipomopsis aggregata (Polemoniaceae) was pollen-limited by adding outcross pollen to open stigmas of plants on 3 occasions at weekly intervals. Experimental pollination doubled the number of flowers producing seed after each occasion and increased the average seed set per fruit for the first one. Plants treated with pollen showed correlations between seed production and height and aborted seed production consistent with resource limitation; untreated, naturally pollinated plants did not. -from Authors

dc:title: Mass movement and erosion of a southern Pennine blanket peat.
dc:creator: Tallis J.
dc:description: Pollen diagrams were compared using five dated horizons between 1580 AD and 3600 BC (calibrated dates). Peat accumulation rates varied considerably, both within and between sites, from about 6 to 96 g/m/yr (measured as dry mass). The onset of erosion was 1000-1200 yr ago. Two features of the growth of the peat blanket on Featherbed Moss are suggested to have been of major importance in ultimately bringing about its degradation and erosion: a very early spread of peat over flatter ground to the limits imposed by topography (so that no further lateral extension was possible); and a rapid build-up of largely unhumified Sphagnum peat over more consolidated peat after 400 AD. The death of Sphagnum from air pollution some 200-300 yr ago led to renewed peat erosion, which is still in progress.-from Author

dc:title: The significance of genetic variation for root growth within a natural population of white clover ( Trifolium repens).
dc:creator: Ennos R.
dc:description: Significant genetic variation in root growth was found within a natural population of white clover. Heritability for this character was high. Genetic variation for root growth within the population had significant effects on the fitness of individuals. Difference in fitness may be attributed to exploitation of slightly different soil layers by the 2 genotypes. -from Author

dc:title: Ecology of achene dimorphism in Heterotheca latifolia. I. Achene structure, germination and dispersal.
dc:creator: Venable D.
dc:description: Describes structural differences between achene types of Heterotheca latifolia (Compositae), when they are produced, where on the plant they are produced, laboratory germination, seedling growth and dispersal biology. -from Authors

dc:title: Late glacial and Holocene sediments at Clarach Bay, near Aberystwyth.
dc:creator: Heyworth A.
dc:description: A largely organic sedimentary sequence, from a site near the mouth of the River Clarach, 2 km north of Aberystwyth, is described. The inland sediments are associated with a submerged forest on the beach. The sediments may be divided into two groups: an earlier, entirely freshwater sequence; and a later series, in which the effects of marine influence may be detected. The first appearance of such effects, at c. 6000 BP, marks the increasing proximity of the coastline, resulting from the Holocene sea-level rise. -from Authors

dc:title: Soils and their related plant communities on the Dalradian limestone of some sites in central Perthshire, Scotland.
dc:creator: Gauld J.
dc:description: 1) For the free-draining soils there is a succession of development corresponding to a progressive increase in leaching. Soil formation is determined by the degree to which the local influence of parent material has countered the regional influence of climate. 2) Soils developed on limestone rock in situ are assigned to the brown rendzina sub-group. 3) Deeper soils developed on the mixed schist-limestone glacial drift are brown forest soils with free drainage. -from Authors

dc:title: The geographical distribution of prickly lettuce ( Lactuca serriola). I. A general survey of its habitats and performance in Britain.
dc:creator: Carter R.N.
dc:description: Populations of the ruderal Lactuca serriola were surveyed near to its northern distribution limit and elsewhere in Britain. The species becomes rarer towards its northern limit and is everywhere restricted to low altitudes, seldom occuring >80 m. Typically, the vegetation of L. serriola sites consists of weedy grasses, annual ruderals and competitive biennial or perennial ruderals. Lactuca serriola itself grows in open patches and shows little association with its cohabitants. Near to its limit, it seldom occurs where competitive ruderals are an important feature of the vegetation. Morphological variation shows little relationship to geographical location. Large plants are seldom found where competitive ruderals are important. The lack of any marked decline in the vigour of L. serriola towards its limits is inconsonant with beliefs generally held about the control of geographical distribution limits. -from Authors

dc:title: Interactions of woody and herbaceous vegetation in a southern African savanna.
dc:creator: Knoop W.
dc:description: The community on a more sandy soil was a broad-leaf woody savanna; the other was a more open microphyllous Acacia community. In the broad-leaf community the effect of the herbaceous vegetation on the woody plants is negligible. In the Acacia community with 7 times more herbaceous biomass, mature woody-plant growth was reduced by competition from the grass-dominated herb layer particularly in the wetter year. Grasses take up topsoil (0-30 cm) water sufficiently rapidly to reduce drainage into the subsoil (30-130 cm), and they also take up subsoil water directly, thus lowering the amount of subsoil water available to woody plants. -from Authors

dc:title: Analysis of frequency and density effects on growth in mixtures of Salvia splendens and Linum grandiflorum using hexagonal fan designs.
dc:creator: Antonovics J.
dc:description: Density had a large effect on vegetative and reproductive weight of Salvia, but a lower effect on Linum, effects consistent with the dwarf, large-broad-leaved habit of Salvia and the tall, small-narrow-leaved habit of Linum. Reproductive effort in Salvia declined with increasing density but increased in Linum. There were complex density and frequency interactions, with the growth of Salvia at low densities being affected by a higher frequency of Salvia, and at high densities being affected by a higher frequency of Linum. At low densities, mixtures tended to give increased yields at low Salvia frequencies, but lower yields at high Salvia frequencies than in monocultures. Hexagonal fan designs provided an approximately 4-fold economy in seeds and nearly a 10-fold economy in space, compared with separate hexagonal plots providing the same range of frequencies and densities, though there are considerable statistical problems associated with the analysis of such designs. -from Authors

dc:title: The integration of neighbourhood effects by clonal genets of Solidago canadensis.
dc:creator: Hartnett D.
dc:description: When clones of Solidago canadensis were grown experimentally with pure stands of different species, the neighbouring species had different effects on ramet shoot-growth, flower-head production, and clonal growth. In general, S. canadensis shoot growth and flower production were greatest in the neighbourhood of Poa pratensis and lowest among Aster pilosus, whereas clonal growth was greatest among ramets growing in the A. pilosus neighbourhood and lowest in the Solidago canadensis neighbourhood. When clones of S. canadensis were grown experimentally with each interconnected ramet among a different neighbour species, the effects of the different neighbours were evened out. Interdependent ramets may support the growth of ramets experiencing intense interference or resource limitation and may benefit from the ability to regulate internally the position and density of shoots within the clone and to overcome local variation in their environment. However, the maintenance of a network of long interconnecting rhizomes may be energetically expensive and may allow certain agents of mortality such as pathogens to spread rapidly among ramets. Within-clonal Solidago canadensis ramets form pure stands, 1-several metres in diameter, that prevent the invasion of neighbours, distribute the effects of surrounding neighbour species, are buffered against neighbour interference, and expand uniformly in several directions regardless of the identity of neighbours. -from Authors

dc:title: Population biology of Clintonia borealis, I. Ramet and patch dynamics.
dc:creator: Pitelka L.
dc:description: Overall ramet mortality rates were size-dependent and low (3.9-6.1%). Rates of clonal growth were low to moderate (5.0-20.6%). Most ramets replaced themselves each year with similar-sized ramets. Although flowering and fruiting occurred, no successful recruitment of new plants from seed was observed. More biomass was allocated to flowers and fruits than to clonal growth. Clonal growth was not reduced by flowering nor vice versa. The environments of individual patches varied widely in terms of light and soil moisture; there were some differences in the rates of ramet mortality and clonal growth, but all patches had annual rates of increase in ramet number of between 2-20%. Small patches often consisted of only 1-2 genets. Patches of only 2-12 ramets typically had ages of 20 yr or more. -from Authors

dc:title: Experimental ecological genetics in Plantago X. The effects of maternal temperature on seed and seedling characters in P. lanceolata.
dc:creator: Alexander H.
dc:description: The importance of temperature experienced during seed maturation (maternal environment) and during germination and seedling growth (progeny environment) on seed and seedling characters was examined in 4 maternal half-sib families of Plantago lanceolata. High maternal temperatures decreased seed weight and increased the percentage germination and an index of germination rate. Families of P. lanceolata responded to the maternal and progeny environments in different ways. The effects of maternal treatments on seed weight, percentage germination, and an index of germination rate were detectable in a 2nd generation. -Authors

dc:title: The establishment of seedlings from primary and regrowth seeds of ragwort ( Senecio jacobaea).
dc:creator: Crawley M.
dc:description: After complete defloration by cinnabar moth Tyria jacobaeae caterpillars, ragwort plants are capable of producing regrowth shoots which flower and produce seed in early autumn of the same year. Regrowth seeds are much lighter (0.26 mg dry weight) than the seeds from primary capitula (0.41 mg). Regrowth seeds showed a slight, but statistically significant, reduction in germination rate (78.8%) compared with the primary seeds (86.4%). In cultivated soil, dug to a fine tilth, both kinds of seeds produced equal numbers of seedlings. In dense, unaltered vegetation, neither kind of seed produced many seedlings. In cut grass, where plant competition was reduced but still substantial, seeds from primary shoots produced just as many seedlings as they did in cultivated, competition-free soil; the smaller seeds from regrowth shoots produced virtually no seedlings. While the smaller regrowth seeds of ragwort are equally viable, they produce seedlings which are substantially less competitive than those from primary shoots. Regrowth seeds presumably increase the fitness of ragwort plants only in those places, or in those years, when competition-free microsites are available for germination in early autumn. -from Authors.

dc:title: On the abundance of plants along an environmental gradient.
dc:creator: Watkinson A.
dc:description: There may be a curvilinear relationship between population size and the net rate of increase of a population along an environmental gradient as a result of the non-linear relationship between growth rate and population density. A consequence of such a curvilinear relationship is that a slight increase in density-independent mortality or a slight reduction in density-independent fecundity can produce a relatively sharp distribution limit along an environmental gradient. The abundance of Cakile edentula was studied along a complex environmental gradient on the sand dunes at Martinique Beach, Nova Scotia. Its population density was greatest in the middle of the dunes and declined to both the landward and seaward ends. The abundance of plants on the dunes as a whole is regulated through the density-dependent control of fecundity on the seaward end of the gradient. The abundance of inidividuals along the gradient is dependent upon the interaction between various density-dependent and density-independent processes. Amongst the latter, the landward migration of seeds is of prime importance. Without migration, populations would not persist in those areas where the species is most abundant in the field. -from Author

dc:title: A reanalysis of interspecific association in an old pasture.
dc:creator: Turkington R.
dc:description: A discussion of various statistical and methodical procedures is followed by a description of means by which a previously relatively clumsy numerical search can be streamlined, and the proposed technique is used to reanalyse data from Turkington & Harper (1979). The reanalysis radically alters the patterns of interspecific associations but in neither case does it affect the general ecological conclusions previously reported. -from Author

dc:title: Thermal adaptation and acclimation of higher plants at the enzyme level: thermostability of NAD malate dehydrogenase in three species of Viola.
dc:creator: Simon J.P.
dc:description: The most thermostable NAD malate dehydrogenase (MDH) was that of Viola fimbriatula, an early successional species, and the most thermolabile that of V. blanda, a species growing in cool, humid and shaded forest understoreys. For Viola sororia, a species occupying a broad range of micro-climates, MDH showed intermediate levels of thermal stability. -from Authors

dc:title: Nutrient content of throughfall and stem flow in woodland recently established on heathland.
dc:creator: Alcock M.R.
dc:description: The nutrient contents of throughfall under a Betula pendula and a Pinus sylvestris canopy were compared with rainfall collected at an adjacent heathland site. The annual nutrient exchange budgets of the tree canopies represented a net leaching of K and Mg and a net absorption of Ca and possibly also of N and P. Nutrient concentrations were negatively correlated with net precipitation at all sites. In most months, K and Mg were leached from the canopy, but for P and N leaching occurred in some months and absorption in others. Calcium was absorbed by the Pinus canopy throughout the year and by the Betula canopy during the summer months. Autumnal peaks in the amounts of throughfall nutrients, which were related to leaf senescence, were shown at both woodland sites for K and N and, at the Betula site, for P also. Spring or early summer peaks were shown for K at both woodland sites. It might be expected that the K and Mg content of the soils under the woodland sites would increase, whilst the Ca, and posibly the P and N contents, may decrease. -from Authors

dc:title: Population biology of Clintonia borealis, II. Survival and growth of transplanted ramets in different environments.
dc:creator: Ashmun J.
dc:description: No adaptive genetic differences were found between plants collected from widely contrasting light regimes. There were no differences in survival and clonal growth in rhizome transplant experiments, but there were differences in mean genet size in the later years of each experiment. Mortality and clonal growth of rhizome transplants were genet size-dependent. After initial high mortality, attributed to transplant shock, the rates of mortality and clonal growth were similar to those observed in natural patches. Most transplanted seeds and their seedlings died. Both mortality and growth in size of seedlings varied significantly among transplant sites. Results show that genets of C. borealis have broad ecological tolerances and few if any easily detectable genetic differences. -from Authors

dc:title: The effects of nitrogen and clipping on interference between C<inf>3</inf> amd C<inf>4</inf> grasses.
dc:creator: Boryslawski Z.
dc:description: Results on the growth of N-deficient plants do not support the hypothesis that C4 plants have greater nitrogen efficiency than C3 species. Temperature is a major factor influencing the outcome of competition. Agropyron smithii (C3) accumulates biomass faster than Bouteloua gracilis (C4) at 20oC day/15oC night conditions. The reverse is true on 30oC day/15oC night. Bouteloua gracilis exhibits a greater resistance to defoliation than A. smithii. Defoliation increases the competitive ability of B. gracilis. -from Authors

dc:title: Small-scale altitudinal variation in lowland and wet tropical forest vegetation.
dc:creator: Lieberman M.
dc:description: All trees and lianas (= or >10 cm dbh) on 12.4 ha of primary lowland wet tropical forest at La Selva, Costa Rica, were enumerated. A total of 5530 live stems were encountered, representing 269 species. Palms comprised 25.5% of stems, lianas 2.4%, tree ferns 0.1% and true trees 72.0%. the most abundant species, Pentaclethra macroloba (Mimosaceae), accounted for 13.6% of stems. Species richness ranged from 79-107 species per ha. Species composition varies continuously with altitude over a range of 39 m. The pool of available species at any altitude is large, and floristic variation between sites at the same altitude is influenced by chance. Seasonally-flooded sites are floristically distinct from sites on higher ground, and show great variation in species composition over short distances. In a 1.8-ha swamp forest, there is a dramatic reduction of stem density and species richness with increasingly poor drainage. This lower number of species reflects the exclusion of species intolerant of waterlogged soils. -from Authors

dc:title: The fifth Tansley Lecture: an experimental approach for the study of ecosystems.
dc:creator: Likens G.
dc:description: Experimental manipulation of whole ecosystems is a powerful analytical approach which provides an opportunity to apply directly the scientific method of testing hypotheses on large and complex systems in their natural setting. Research undertaken at the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest, West Thornton, New Hampshire is reviewed, with emphasis on the long-term data base and attention focusing on experimental studies of deforestation, though experimental studies of stream ecosystems - including acidification - are also noted. -P.J.Jarvis

dc:title: The geographical distribution of prickly lettuce ( Lactuca serriola). III. Its performance in transplant sites beyond its distribution limit in Britain.
dc:creator: Prince S.D.
dc:description: The annual ruderal Lactuca serriola, confined in England to the SE, was introduced into sites in the NW (Cheshire) and the SW (Devon and Cornwall). Seeds sown early in autumn germinated quickly; seeds sown later germinated sporadically until December. Germination was affected by soil-type, rainfall and temperature, but was unimpaired beyond its distribution limit. Winter growth was faster in warmer sites regardless of location. In Cheshire, plants had slightly lower winter dry weights and relative growth rates than in Essex, but the faster growth was recorded in the SW. Differences in the pattern of growth between Essex and Cheshire were reflected in higher leaf weight ratios among the Cheshire plants. Differences disappeared when rapid growth started in spring. Development towards flowering and fruiting was faster within its distribution limit, but vernalized plants beyond the limit always shed their seeds before the onset of winter. No differences in fecundity within and beyond its limit were detected. Vernalization was usually essential for the plant to complete its life-cycle, but in the exceptionally hot summer of 1976 some non-vernalized plants produced seed within its limit. At mean temperatures >20oC development towards flowering was only slightly hastened, whereas <14oC it was delayed considerably. The responses of individuals must be related to their secondary effects on populations and metapopulations if the distribution limit of L. serriola is to be understood. -from Authors

dc:title: Effects of bryophytes on seedling emergence and establishment of short-lived forbs in chalk grassland.
dc:creator: Keizer P.J.
dc:description: Seedling emergence in a Dutch chalk grassland was negatively correlated with bryophyte cover in Carlina vulgaris, Euphrasia officinalis and to a lesser extent in Linum catharticum; no significant correlation could be found for Gentianella germanica or Scabiosa columbaria. Seedling mortality was lower with high bryophyte cover in C. vulgaris and L. cartharticum. Removal of bryophytes in the previous autumn increased emergence and survival in L. catharticum, but had no effect on the other species. Radiant flux and red/far-red quotient were reduced below a bryophyte cover. -from Authors

dc:title: Demography of two facultative biennial plant species in an unproductive habitat.
dc:creator: Klemow K.
dc:description: Populations of Echium vulgare and Picris hieracioides were monitored in an abandoned limestone quarry near Syracuse, New York. The demography of P. hieracioides differed greatly on 2 sites: on the dense site, more seedlings emerged and a greater proportion established, probably due to the higher water retention than on the sparse site. Conversely, a lower proportion of plants at the dense site survived to maturity, reproduction was delayed, and there was reduced seed output by mature plants, possibly due to competition. Survival and reproduction was highest in the year with the most rainfall during the growing season. Populations declined during the study on both sites, apparently because of low survival and establishment of seedlings during 4 subsequent years of drought. Populations persisted through the dry years by reproductive delay coupled with comparatively high survival of established plants. In Echium vulgare, only reproduction was delayed longer on the dense site. Rates of survival from seedling emergence to maturity were as high during years of drought as when rainfall was abundant. Populations of E. vulgare increased even during 4 years of drought, suggesting that the species may have only recently begun colonizing the quarry. -from Authors

dc:title: Biotic specialization between neightbouring genotypes in Lolium perenne and Trifolium repens from a permanent pasture.
dc:creator: Aarssen L.
dc:description: Samples of Lolium perenne and Trifolium repens were collected as neighbouring pairs from 4 different localities in a 40-year-old pasture. Each grass-genet-type was planted, as cloned ramets, in competition with each clover-genet-type in all possible combinations. Each clover-genet-type generally produced more dry weight when grown with the grass-genet-associate with which it was collected than with others. The converse was true for the grass genets. The grass yielded more than the clover in all combinations, but members of natural-neighbouring genet pairs contributed more equitably to the total yield than other pairs. Natural-neighbouring pairs, however, did not differ significantly in total yield from pairs of non-natural neighbours. Results suggest the presence of precisely-defined biotic specialization in several neighbouring genotype pairs, all belonging to the same 2 species in different localities of a single community. Natural neighbours have more balanced competitive abilities for contested resources than do non-natural neighbours. This relationship may be based on the relatively high mobility of T. repens cones through stolon extension, and the opportunity for concomitant competition and beneficence (through N enrichment from symbiotic Rhizobium) between these species. Natural selection, in contexts of competition, may result in more balanced competitive abilities for contested resources instead of niche differentiation. This may be an important evolutionary mechanism of coexistence. -from Authors

dc:title: The geographical distribution of prickly lettuce ( Lactuca serriola). II. Characteristics of populations near its distribution limit in Britain.
dc:creator: Prince S.D.
dc:description: Lactuca serriola is a winter or spring annual weed confined in England to the south-east. Each summer from 1976-1981 counts were made of its numbers between posts 100 m apart along the length of the M5 motorway (Exeter-Birmingham, 250 km). This motorway twice crosses the geographical distribution limit of L. serriola and its verges provide a set of habitable sites for the species in which local variation is minimized so that geographical trends in its abundance can be discerned. Distribution on the motorway was closely related to altitude; it seldom occurred >85 m, but <60 m it was common. Colonies did not become smaller or sparser towards its northern or southern distribution limits which were therefore abrupt both spatially and relative to the environmental gradients. There was a large and unexpected increase in its abundance and range in 1977 compared with 1976 probably caused by the exceptional hot dry weather of 1976. In subsequent years its population density slowly returned to that of 1976. Such abrupt geographical distribution limits, seldom identified, may be frequent in fugitive species. -from Authors

dc:title: Effect of microtopography on the survival and reproduction of Medicago lupulina.
dc:creator: Pavone L.
dc:description: Density of Medicago lupulina, a short-lived perennial herb, decreased from the top (ridge) to the bottom (hollow) of shallow depressions (0.5-1 m deep) in an abandoned pasture in S Ontario. Plants growing on moss-covered ridges had a greater life expectancy and were more likely to produce seeds before dying than were plants growing on moss-free ridges or in hollows. Shading, by grasses and herbs, was probably responsible for the relatively poor survival and reproduction of M. lupulina in hollows. Shading was less intense on ridges and, where a ground cover of mosses maintained damper conditions, both the life expectancy and reproduction of M. lupulina increased. Grazing and trampling increased the life expectancy of plants in hollows, probably by improving the light regime, but animals had no significant effect on the expected life span of plants on ridges. The number of seedlings recruited from the seed bank did not differ significantly between study plots on ridges and in hollows, so it is more likely that the difference in adult density resulted from differential survival of seedlings. -from Authors

dc:title: Nitrogen source and the tolerance of Deschampsia flexuosa, Holcus lanatus and Bromus erectus to aluminium during seedling growth.
dc:creator: Rorison I.H.
dc:description: Deschampsia flexuosa grew equally fast with either NO3-N or NH4-N as the N source. It was tolerant of any combination of N source and Al except for the highest concentration of Al (5.4mg l-1) supplied with NO3-N. Holcus lanatus grew significantly faster in NO3-N than it did in NH4N and showed classical symptoms of Al toxicity in the presence of NO3-N. The strongly adverse effect of NH4-N was significantly ameliorated by Al addition. Bromus erectus also grew significantly faster in NO3-N than it did in NH4-N and was susceptible to Al toxicity in the presence of NO3-N. The very small extent of growth in NH4-N masked any possible effects of Al; growth was not increased in the presence of Al. A revision of ideas on the roles of inorganic toxins in acidic soils is proposed.-from Author

dc:title: The population biology of plants with clonal growth. III. Analysis of tiller mortality in Carex arenaria.
dc:creator: Bartlett N.
dc:description: Tiller survival in the rhizomatous sedge Carex arenaria was studied in 2 sand dune-slack systems on Anglesey, N Wales. Application of NPK fertilizer led to a large increase in the numbers of shoots that emerged for the mature and senile phases but only a modest increase for the slack phase. Mortality rates for 3 of the 5 cohorts (April, June and September), in both control and fertilized quadrats did not differ greatly for the time intervals that they had in common but differed significantly from the mortality rates of the other cohorts (July and January). The cohorts from the mature and senile phases had similar mortality rates except for the fertilized quadrats at one of the 2 sites. Application of fertilizer led to higher mortality for the mature and senile phases; this was not the case for the slack phase. -from Authors

dc:title: Plant zonation and the effects of the spring-neap tidal cycle on soil aeration in a Humber salt marsh.
dc:creator: Armstrong W.
dc:description: Three main soil-aeration patterns emerged. The 1st with reducing conditions persisting throughout much of the profile and indifferent to periods of exposure, was characteristic of Spartina anglica sites; only near the surface (= or <5 cm) and at neap periods were there phases of oxidation. The 2nd was found in Puccinellia maritima-, creek bank (Halimione portulacoides)- and Elymus pycanthus-sites; redox potentials were lowered monthly by the high spring tides but at the creek-bank- and Elymus-sites potentials rarely fell <200 mV and were responsive to high or very high spring tides only. In the 'general salt marsh' zone and its sub-sites (including Festuca hummocks) only the very high spring tides influenced aeration producing a 3rd pattern in which there was a longer period of oxidation, free from fluctuation, than at any other site. Results are discussed in relation to known responses of the species to soil flooding. -from Authors

dc:title: Plasticity in yield components in response to fruit predation and date of fruit initiation in three species of Sesbania ( Leguminosae).
dc:creator: Marshall D.
dc:description: Removal of fruits, which mimic damage by chewing insects, resulted in significant changes in seed weight but not in seeds produced per fruit. Injection of alcohol into developing seeds, mimicking damage by hemipterans, resulted in selective abortion of more heavily damaged fruits and of younger fruits. Responses become less flexible as development proceeds. Differential responses to predation among the species appeared to be related to the investment in seeds versus pods, since S. vesicaria, which had the highest quotient of seed weight to fruit weight, had the highest rate of fruit abortion. Fruits initiated on later dates were less likely to mature in all 3 species. Late fruits had an unchanged number of ovules but reduced seed size in S. macrocarpa (annual), reduced ovule number but unchanged seed size in S. vesicaria (annual), and unchanged ovule number and seed size in S. drummondii (perennial). Each annual species apparently holds most constant the yield component most closely related to fitness, while the perennial is less responsive to stress because its stored reserves provide a buffer. -from Authors

dc:title: Vegetation dynamics and neighbour associations in pasture- community evolution.
dc:creator: Aarssen L.
dc:description: Relative abundances of species differed in 3 different-aged pasture communities with similar management histories, but there were no significant differences in species diversity or composition. Ordination of percentage-cover data from all surveys established a trend of increasing community stability, or constancy, with increasing pasture age. Patterns of association in time between species were investigated with contact sampling. Four different patterns were identified. Between-species associations in younger communities were predominantly temporary, while older communities had more persistent associations. Data form the basis of a qualitative model of pasture-community evolution which attributes within-community changes in time to biotic interactions between neighbours. -from Authors

dc:title: Ecological effects of heather burning. II. Effects on seed germination and vegetative regeneration.
dc:creator: Mallik A.
dc:description: In Calluna-dominated heathlands managed by periodic burning, vegetation composition is influenced by the ability of species to regenerate rapidly after a fire. In Genista anglica and Hypericum pulchrum, evidence was obtained of stimulation of germination following short periods (30 s-2 min) of pre-treatment at 100oC. There was some indication that in Vaccinium vitis-idaea a vernalization requirement might be over-ridden by a very short period of heating at 100oC. Apart from these instances, there was little evidence of 'fire-adaptation' of this kind. Treatments at 200oC, or for more than 2 min at 100oC, either killed seeds or reduced germination in most of the species tested. All tested species (except Juniperus communis) regenerated vegetatively after burning at 600oC; in most cases a temperature of 800oC resulted in less recovery. Findings emphasize the importance of controlling management fires so that canopy temperatures are held within the range 400-600oC and ground-surface temperatures rise little above 100oC. These conditions should be sustained for no more than 2 min as the fire passes through the vegetation. -from Authors

dc:title: The canopy structure and microclimate of papyrus ( Cyperus papyrus) swamps.
dc:creator: Jones M.
dc:description: Papyrus swamps at Lake Naivasha, Kenya and at Busoro, Rwanda, were investigated. Aerial biomass was 3245 g m-2 at Naivasha, and 1384 g m-2 at Busoro while the culm densities were 12.7 m-2 and 17.9 m-2, respectively. Combined data from several sites give a linear relationship between aerial biomass and culm density but it does not follow the thinning rule (-3/2 power law). Papyrus umbels on mature culms were larger at Naivasha than at Busoro; their photosynthetic tissues (rays + bracteoles) had mean surface areas per culm of 6245 cm2 and 5242 cm2, respectively. The area of photosynthetic tissue per unit ground area (umbel area index) was 7.0 at Naivasha and 8.1 at Busoro. The chlorophyll content of the photosynthetic tissue was similar to that recorded for other emergent macrophytes. Light interception by the canopy was virtually complete. The Naivasha site experienced daily mean temperatures 3oC, and mean minimum temperatures 10oC, lower than at Busoro. This may account for the higher biomass at Naivasha, because lower night temperatures reduce respiratory losses. There were differences in the root environment at the 2 sites with lower conductivity, redox potential and N concentration at Busoro. This suggests that growing conditions at Busoro were 'poorer' than at Naivasha. -from Authors

dc:title: The genet and ramet population dynamics of Solidago canadensis in an abandoned field.
dc:creator: Hartnett D.
dc:description: Invasion by Solidago canadensis of an old field in east-central Illinois occurred mainly during the 3rd, 4th and 5th years after the field was abandoned. There was no recruitment after the 6th year, but rapid clonal expansion of the established genets caused ramet densities to continue to increase for several years. Both genet survivorship and clonal growth were inversely related to the time of recruitment, so that after a few years the populations were composed mainly of genets that had established during the 1st year of colonization. Genet density reached a maximum in the 5th year, then slowly declined. -from Authors

dc:title: Experimental estimates of census efficiency and pseudoturnover on islands: error trend and between-observer variation when recording vascular plants.
dc:creator: Nilsson I.
dc:description: Vascular plant species on 41 small islands in Lake Mockeln, southern Sweden were recorded in 1976, 1978, 1980 and 1982. In 1982 the counts were made by 2 independent teams. Census time per island increased over time to >200 man-minutes ha-1 in 1982. Similarly, the number of species recorded per island increased with time. In 1982, both teams had similar census efficiency which was, at most, 79%. Between-team pseudoturnover was significantly lower. Pseudoturnover was negatively correlated with island area. Implications for tests of island biogeographic theory are discussed. The number of species found on each island in at least one of the years 1976-80, but not in 1982, as a percentage of the total number found on that island in 1982 was c5%. This percentage, a maximum estimate of local population extinction, was negatively correlated with island area. At most, 1% of the vascular plant species present on an island becomes extinct each year. -from Authors

dc:title: Post-fire recruitment and mortality in a population of the mallee Eucalyptus incrassata in semi-arid south-eastern Australia.
dc:creator: Wellington A.B.
dc:description: Study of the population dynamics of yellow mallee based upon the life-stage approach revealed that the populations are not static under present conditions. Successful establishment of seedlings is rare and is restricted to recently-burnt stands. Seedling recruitment of mallee eucalypts is uncommon, even following fire. This phenomenon may result from the infrequent coincidence of fire and years favourable for germination and establishment. Recruitment events are thus widely spaced in time, imparting a steady-state appearance to mallee populations. -from Authors

dc:title: Relative growth of six thistle species along a nutrient gradient with multispecies competition.
dc:creator: Austin M.P.
dc:description: Seedlings of Carduus nutans, C. 'pycnocephalus', Carthamus lanatus, Cirsium vulgare, Onopordum aff. illyricum and Silybum marianum common in mixed pastures of SE Australia, were grown in pots of sand to each of which 1 to 12 concentrations of nutrient solution was applied regularly for 14 wk. The species were grown either as monocultures or in mixtures. The total yield of all species increased in monocultures and in mixtures with increasing total nutrients. Nutrients, species and nutrient X species interactions were significant for both monocultures and mixtures. When species performance in monoculture was expressed on a relative basis (relative physiological performance) most showed a characteristic response; only Onopordum and Silybum were similar. Prediction of thistle performance in multispecies mixture was possible from monoculture performance, but the predictive model differed for each of 3 zones along the nutrient concentration gradient. -from Authors

dc:title: Nutrient retention by savanna ecosystems III. Response to artificial loading.
dc:creator: Kellman M.
dc:description: The ability of 3 types of savanna in Belize to retain large influxes of nutrient elements was evaluated by adding to each a large quantity of Ca, Mg, K, Na and P in solution at weekly intervals. Rapid short-term immobilization was observed at all sites after each addition, but leakage was evident as solution concentrations in the deeper soil layers were significantly greater than those measured previously under untreated conditions. Leakage was greatest beneath a Quercus oleoides thicket, least beneath grassland, and intermediate beneath an open stand of Pinus caribaea. These differences corresponded to major contrasts in soil properties. Element retention is attributed mainly to adsorption by soil cation-exchange complexes. -from Author

dc:title: Comparative studies of diet selection by sheep and cattle: the hill grasslands.
dc:creator: Grant S.
dc:description: A comparative study was made of the seasonal variation in floristic composition of the diets selected by sheep and cattle grazing together on Agrostis-Festuca, Nardus and Molinia grassland communities in S Scotland. Sheep diets were more variable than cattle diets, both between and within animals, for all sites. Sheep and cattle differed significantly for almost all major dietary components; exceptions were Molinia leaf, grass sheath and dead material at the Molinia site. Differences between sheep and cattle diets were explicable by 1) a difference in the height at which the animals grazed in relation to differences in the distribution of plant species within the sward canopy. 2) the greater ability of sheep to select from fine-scale mixtures; and 3) the greater readiness of cattle to graze tall, more fibrous components. -from Authors

dc:title: Ecology of achene dimorphism in Heterotheca latifolia. II. Demographic variation within populations.
dc:creator: Venable D.
dc:description: The capacity for population increase of H. latifolia is high with the contribution from disc achenes usually considerably more important than that of ray achenes. Plants derived from ray achenes will contribute more, relative to those derived from disc achenes, in declining populations or populations in which disturbance reduces the survival of the growth stage more than the survival of the dormant seed stage.-from Authors

dc:title: Nutrient retention by savanna ecosystems I. Retention in the absence of fire.
dc:creator: Kellman M.
dc:description: The soil-water percolation regime and the concentration of Ca, Mg, K, Na and P in the soil solution were determined daily at 5 soil depths beneath 3 types of savanna in Belize, during wet- and dry-season conditions, in the absence of fire. The nutrient concentration of the surface-soil solutions were consistently higher than those of the bulk precipitation, throughfall, and those in deeper soil layers, but there was no evidence of any acute movement of nutrients to deeper soil layers, attributed to the capacity of the soil to immobilize rapidly any large quantities of nutrients appearing in solution. There was no evidence that root uptake was an important mechanism of short-term nutrient retention at these sites. These oligotrophic soil-vegetation systems are highly retentive of nutrients and are not subject to large short-term losses in the absence of fire.-from Authors

dc:title: Succession of vegetation in an evolving river delta, Atchafalaya Bay, Louisiana.
dc:creator: Johnson W.
dc:description: Three vegetation associations explained the most variance in the spring and autumn analyses and also occupied the greatest area. Each was dominated by a single species: Sagittaria latifolia, Salix nigra or Typha latifolia. In each of these associations diversity was low. Measurement of the similarity in species composition among the main associations showed little overlap among them. More complex seasonally-changing plant associations, with high diversity and greater spatial overlap, are developing on the delta islands, but at present occupy little area. Analysis of soil nutrients revealed little variation with season or plant association. In contrast, the percentage variation in water level, organic carbon, and percentage sand with season and plant association was substantial. Hydrologic influences on the delta island seem to have the greatest influence on distribution of vegetation. -from Authors

dc:title: Survival, fecundity and growth of wild cucumber, Echinocystis lobata.
dc:creator: Silvertown J.
dc:description: Echinocystis lobata (Cucurbitaceae) is a climbing, monoecious annual of damp places which rarely occurs in the dense stands typical of other annuals. Plants are protandrous, and flower late in the life cycle. An evolutionary explanation is offered for late flowering in terms of the relationship between plant size and fecunity and the vegetative costs of fruit production. The size-frequency distribution of plants developed a right-handed skew with time and showed similarities with distributions observed in populations of other species growing on quite different ecological conditions.-from Author

dc:title: Population dynamics of Oenothera glazioviana in a sand- dune system with special reference to the adaptive significance of size- dependent reproduction.
dc:creator: Kachi N.
dc:description: Oenothera glazioviana (a facultative biennial) behaves as a short-lived monocarpic perennial in an infertile sand-dune system at Azigaura. Japan. Both annual mortality and relative growth rate were negatively correlated with plant size. Comparisons of a size-specific model with an age specific model revealed that size-specific reproduction always resulted in higher r. This advantage increases in a changing environment, because in size-specific reproduction, plants reproduce at different ages and use the changing environment as fine-grained, while in age- specific reproduction, plants reproduce simultaneously and use the changing environment as coarse-grained.-from Authors

dc:title: Effects of herbivory by moose on flower and fruit production of Aralia nudicaulis.
dc:creator: Edwards H.
dc:description: On Isle Royale, Michigan, grazing of Aralia nudicaulis by Alces alces was intense: 63% of flowering shoots and 33% of vegetative shoots were eaten. The proportion of shoots eaten increased with shoot density from 11% in quadrats with <9 shoots m-2 to 77% in quadrats with >20 shoots m-2. The impact of this on Aralia population structure is shown. -from Author

dc:title: Clonal growth in grassland perennials II. Growth form and fine- scale colonizing ability.
dc:creator: Schmid B.
dc:description: In lawn communities, the rosette density of Bellis perennis was stable with time and little affected by removal of either grasses or dicotyledonous species. In Prunella vulgaris, the module density changed greatly with time and was influenced by the presence of other dicotyledonous species in the sward. These differences are interpreted as typical of phalanx and guerrilla species. Leaves were shorter-lived in B. perennis, where they shade each other more than in P. vulgaris. The longevity of leaves of both species is high during winter but low during the growing season. The phalanx species B. perennis colonizes small bare patches mainly with seedlings, but the guerrilla species P. vulgaris colonizes mainly by clonal growth. Seedlings which attained adulthood were observed in B. perennis but not in P. vulgaris.-from Author

dc:title: Ecology of achene dimorphism in Heterotheca latifolia III. Consequences of varied water availability.
dc:creator: Venable D.
dc:description: Disc achenes were more successful than ray achenes when a plentiful water supply resulted in a high overall biomass and density at the end of the experiment. The inferior performance of ray achenes is attributed to the combined effects of lower embryo provisioning, lower and germination, and suppression by the early-germinating disc achenes. Ray achenes were more successful than disc achenes when water was scarce and overall biomass and density were low at the end of the experiment. Their superior performance resulted from escaping the water shortage by dormancy.-from Author

dc:title: The light requirement for germination of Aster pilosus seeds: temporal aspects and ecological consequences.
dc:creator: Baskin J.
dc:description: Apparently, only after they become non-dormant during winter can seeds be light-stimulated to high germination percentages in darkness in spring. Thus, seeds that become buried in autumn or early winter should not germinate in spring, whereas if no other factors of the soil environment besides darkness prevent germination, seeds that become buried in late winter should germinate in spring.-from Authors

dc:title: Mortality patterns and stand turnover rates in a wet tropical forest in Costa Rica.
dc:creator: Lieberman D.
dc:description: Mortality over 13yr period was determined for all stems (= or >10cm dbh) on 12.4ha of primary lowland wet tropical forest at La Selva; 23.2% of 5623 trees and lianas present in the initial inventory had died by the time of the subsequent inventory. Mortality rates were independent of size among individuals = or >10cm dbh, and did not differ between buttressed and non- buttressed stems. Of the dead individuals, 26% died standing, 31% had fallen, 7% were found buried under treefalls, and 37% had decomposed entirely. Mortality was nearly balanced by recruitment into the 10cm dbh class; there was a net loss of 1.7% of stems in 13yr. La Selva appears to be among the most dynamic of tropical forests studied to date, with an annual loss of stems of 2.03% and a consequent stand half-life of 34yr.-from Authors

dc:title: On non-Darcian water flow in peat.
dc:creator: Hemond H.
dc:description: The movement of water through mires is a controlling ecological factor, since the transport of solutes by advection can dominate nutrient fluxes, determine the growth rates or survival of plants, and profoundly influence peat redox status and decomposition rates. The existing literature suggests that such flow violates Darcy's Law in humified peats, and casts doubt on the applicability of existing models for flow through porous media when applied to peatlands. -from Authors

dc:title: Nutrient retention by savanna ecosystems II. Retention after fire.
dc:creator: Kellman M.
dc:description: The daily patterns of precipitation, soil water movement, and the concentration of nutrient elements in soil solutions at 5 depths were examined beneath 3 types of savanna in Belize, after burning. Large increases in the concentration of some elements were recorded in the rooting zones in all types, but these disappeared within 1 wk. Results confirm the resistance of the 3 savanna types to acute losses of nutrients due to leaching after fire. Greater losses are likely to result from surface run-off during rainstroms. However, repeated burning has not significantly reduced the fertility of the surface soil, but has significantly increased the amounts of Ca and Mg in the soil exchange complex.-from Authors

dc:title: Markov models and succession: a test from a heathland in the Netherlands.
dc:creator: Lippe E.
dc:description: A Markov chain model is examined for an Empetrum nigrum heath in The Netherlands, based upon observations over 19yr. The assumption that the transition probabilities are stationary does not hold for these data. The transition matrix is affected by 1) identifiable influences due to climate and insect plagues; 2) directional changes of the transition probabilities with time; and 3) spatial influences.-from Authors

dc:title: Clonal growth in grassland perennials III. Genetic variation and plasticity between and within populations of Bellis perennis and Prunella vulgaris.
dc:creator: Schmid B.
dc:description: Suggests that plasticity is high in Bellis perennis because genets remain in relatively fixed positions (phalanx growth habit) . Evolution of local specialization in Prunella vulgaris may be explained by the ability of genets to travel by clonal growth (guerrilla growth habit) and to find favourable patches in the environment.-from Author

dc:title: Effects of seed size and microsite on seedling emergence of Prunella vulgaris in four habitats.
dc:creator: Winn A.
dc:description: In general, large seeds had a higher percentage emergence. Litter and herbaceous cover inhibited seedling emergence in woodland habitats; herbaceous cover inhibited emergence in old-field habitats. In all habitats, larger seeds had less stringent requirements. Within a habitat, the magnitude of the effect of seed size on seedling emergence may be influenced by mean size of seeds produced and abundance of microsites favourable for germination. Seed size is a phenotypically plastic characteristic in P. vulgaris.-from Author

dc:title: Frequency-dependent grazing by slugs and grasshoppers.
dc:creator: Cottam D.
dc:description: Frequency-dependent grazing was investigated in the slug Deroceras reticulatum, feeding on mixtures of Dactylis glomerata and Trifolium repens, and in the grasshopper, Omocestus viridulus, feeding on 5 grass species in paired combinations. D. reticulatum grazed disproportionately on the rarer species and showed a marked preference for T. repens. O. viridulus grazed disproportionately on the commoner species between some pairs of grasses but not others. These types of grazing behaviour possibly arise because D. reticulatum seeks a varied diet and O. viridulus becomes conditioned onto the most abundant food. -from Author

dc:title: Plant zonation on a shoreline gradient: physiological response curves of component species.
dc:creator: Wilson S.
dc:description: Distributions of 12 shoreline plant species were measured along a gradient of substratum organic content in 6 Canadian lakes. Differential distributions of the species along the gradient are not entirely attributable to differential physiological responses.- from Authors

dc:title: Allelopathic effects of Trichostema lanceolatum ( Labiatae) in the California annual grassland.
dc:creator: Heisey R.
dc:description: Trichostema lanceolatum contains 2.9% volatile essential oil in its fresh foliage. The allelopathic potential of T. lanceolatum under natural conditions, however, appears to be low.-from Authors

dc:title: Within-species diversity in natural populations of Holcus lanatus, Lolium perenne ad Trifolium repens from four different- aged pastures.
dc:creator: Aarssen L.
dc:description: Variability was large within each population of Holcus lanatus, Lolium perenne and Trifolium repens from different-aged pastures in the lower Fraser Valley, British Columbia, but all 3 species showed significant differences in the quantity of variation present among the different-aged pastures. Many characters, especially for L. perenne and T. repens, showed a decline in mean values and variance with increasing pasture age. The overall high diversity may have been maintained by a heterogeneous biotic environment and the general decline in diversity may be attributable to continuous elimination of the less-fit genotypes by competition and grazing. -from Authors

dc:title: Clonal growth in grassland perennials I. Density and pattern- dependent competition between plants with different growth forms.
dc:creator: Schmid B.
dc:description: Cones of Bellis perennis have tightly aggregated rosettes (phalanx type) and vary little in size. Rosette populations grow logistically, probably regulated by change in birth rate. Branches of Prunella vulgaris are only loosely aggregated within clones (guerrilla type). The frequency distribution of clone sizes in P. vulgaris is hierarchical. Branch populations grow exponentially and exceed the equilibrium density before regulation, through increased death rate, occurs. No differences in intensity of competition within and between clones were found in either species. P. vulgaris showed a more fugitive behaviour in mixed than in pure populations. Competition was density-dependent; in mixtures of B. perennis and P. vulgaris the phalanx species was aggressive at high but suppressed at low densities and the guerrilla species was aggressive at low but suppressed at high densities. This outcome is caused by the differences in growth form of the 2 species. -from Authors

dc:title: Herbivore exclosure and competitor removal: effects on juvenile survivorship and growth in the shrub Gutierrezia microcephala.
dc:creator: Parker M.
dc:description: In arid grasslands of central New Mexico, Gutierrezia microcephala is atacked by the specialist grasshopper Hesperotettix viridis. In 1980, 93% of plants in the natural vegetation were defoliated. The frequecy of defoliation did not vary with plant size, distance from mature conspecifics, or with local vegetation composition. Annual mortality of 2nd year plants protected from grasshoppers was 89% and did not vary when either conspecifics or perennial grasses or both types of competitors were removed from within 0.5m of each plant. The death rate for plants exposed to grasshoppers was greatly affected by the presence of neighbouring plants; it ranged from 22% when all neighbouring plants were removed to 47% when the vegetation was left intact. Protection from herbivory significantly increased plant growth in the following year (plant height, number of stems). Growth was also significantly increased by removal of nearby perennial grasses. G. microcephala gradually becomes tolerant both to herbivore attack and between species competition during its ontogeny.-from Authors
